data.title: State Historical Society of North Dakota
data.text:
Title: Kermit Karns

Dates: ca. 1914-2014

Collection Number: MSS 10804

Quantity: 12 feet/17 microfilm rolls (#06975-06977, 07005-07007, 17313-17322)

Abstract: Includes records from churches and cemeteries in McIntosh County (N.D.), published church and family histories, research on McPherson County (S.D.), photographs of family and friends, newspaper clippings about people, places, genealogy and events, and extensive research files that primarily contain correspondence about Karns' genealogical research, conducted for others, for the American Family Records Association, or for his own use. Significant topics within Karns' research files include Germans from Russia and McIntosh County (N.D.).

Provenance: The Kermit Karns Papers were donated to the State Historical Society of North Dakota by Kermit B. Karns between 2000-2014. Material was added to the collection in May 2016.

Property Rights: The State Historical Society of North Dakota owns the property rights to this collection.

Copyrights: Copyrights to this collection remain with the donor, publisher, author, or author's heirs. Researchers should consult the 1976 Copyright Act, Public Law 94-553, Title 17, U.S. Code or an archivist at this repository if clarification of copyright requirements is needed.

Access: This collection is open under the rules and regulations of the State Historical Society of North Dakota.

Citation: Researchers are requested to cite the collection title, collection number, and the State Historical Society of North Dakota in all footnote and bibliographic references.

Transfer: Publications from the collection were offered to the State Archives Publications in May 2016.

BIOGRAPHICAL SKETCH

By Kermit B. Karns, August 1997

Born January 17, 1917, Chamberlain, SD, to Thomas and Ida (Bury) Karns. Raised north of Miles City, MT. Graduated from grade school in 1930 with honors. Studied electricity and mechanics. Enrolled in Civilian Conservation Corp 1935-1937 as axeman, tractor operator, truck driver, company clerk, canteen steward, mechanic. Married 1937 to Lottie Wolf a daughter of Germans-from- Russia living at Danzig, ND. 3 children. Entered Federal Government service in 1937 as Flight Service Station operator, changed to electronic maintenance technician in 1947, changed to electronic engineer in 1955. Retired from Federal Aviation Administration in 1972 at Kansas City, Missouri.

In my federal employment, I took weather observations, operated and maintained Teletype, radio and mechanical equipment, communicated by radio with aircraft pilots, conducted airway communication operations, conducted electronic and mechanical maintenance. Also, investigated defects in airway equipment design and operation; developed many fixes. In addition, conducted electronic engineering relating to ground siting of air navigation radio facilities, supervised various operations relating to electronic installation, leased telephone services, radio frequency management, non-federal aviation aids, etc. All this involved the preparation of much written material. Became involved in genealogy in 1953. Researched own KARNS line back to about 1833 when they arrived in Tuscarawas County, Ohio, from Switzerland. Researched wife’s WOLF line back through South Russia and into Schaubach Esslingen-Wurtemburg, Germany in 1797.

Have held various jobs in numerous professional, technical, genealogical and historical societies. Was instrumental in founding several organizations: American Family Records Association, Missouri State Genealogical Association; Kansas City Adult Adoptees Organization, Kansas City Chapter of the National Micrographics Association, Clay County (Missouri) Archives, Clay County (Missouri) Museum and Historical Society, Greater Kansas City Chapter of the American Historical Society of Germans from Russia. Have given talks on genealogically related subjects over the years to numerous groups. Have prepared considerable material for publication on those same subjects for various journals.

In 1961, developed a genealogical data base format using library catalog cards for the storage medium. About 40,000 cards were prepared for use at the Kansas City Public Library. In 1966, started a data base of Germans-from-Russia related to McIntosh County, North Dakota and McPherson County, South Dakota. This developed into about 60,000 cards when the collection was turned over to the Library at Aberdeen, South Dakota for public use. In the mid-1970s, completed a reading of all tombstone inscriptions in McIntosh County which was published by the Bismarck-Mandan Historical and Genealogical Society in 1978.

Became involved in microfilming in 1974. Microfilmed some 50 rolls of church and county records, and directories, of North Dakota, South Dakota, and Nebraska in about 10 years.

Several years ago, I began to enter German-Russia genealogy related to McIntosh County into a computer. That file now stands at about 5 megabytes of data - some 1300 pages. Included are records of cemeteries, births, marriages, deaths, churches, etc. Special approval was given by the North Dakota Department of Vital Records to microfilm birth information but with the restriction that the file be available for use only by the Library Research Staff of the State Historical Society of North Dakota.

From the McCook County Gazette:

Kermit Karns, 97, died Sunday (Nov. 30, 2014) at Imperial Manor Nursing Home in Imperial. Survivors include children, Celia Spady of Champion, Nebraska, Dick Karns and wife, Loretta, of Kearney, Missouri, and John Karns of Liberty, Missouri; five grandchildren, 15 great-grandchildren and three great-great-grandchildren. Memorial services are Thursday, Dec. 4, 2014, 10 a.m. (MT) at United Methodist Church of Imperial with the Rev. Valera Heyenberk officiating. Interment will follow at Mount Hope Cemetery in Imperial.
